A campaign site for Taiwanese watch manufacturer ATOP

I only knew two things about Taiwan. Before I discovered the joys of MacBooks, I used to put together my own Windows builds because I am a huge dweeb. A key component of any PC is its motherboard. This is like the central nervous system of a computer and therefore one of its most important parts. A trusted name in mid-level motherboards at the time was ASUS, a manufacturer from Taiwan. This is all I knew about Taiwan until I came across these watches. Secondly, the U.S. refuses to recognise China as an independent country. None of that is relevant.

Findings

This project went through three rounds and by comparing v1 with v3, I can chart my progression as a designer in that time (2013â€“2016) . Here are my realisations:

  • Use vectors when you can
  • Control all the things that youâ€™re able to control.
  • Design and control on the web is really large and interesting subject
  • Get out of the way. Focus on the important.

SVG all the things

By constructing our watch with vectors, weâ€™re able to have control over the entire thing within code. We can even change the time to match that of the usersâ€™.

Leveraging the power of SVG sprites means we only need to define this once, then pass in styles to get our seperate watches. Unfortunately, we canâ€™t dial in to the path itself, so we need to position: absolute them on top one another to achieve this.

Constructing the grid

The precisoin used in the manufacturing the watch needed to be conveyed in its presentation. In 2011, Mark Boulton wrote A Richer Canvas, a treatise on web layout which confronted the incorrect model we had been using to construct grids on the web. Itâ€™s as important today as it was back then and I encourage you to read it if you work on the web. This was my first opportunity to put the â€˜content outâ€™ methodology into practice.Â 

300 is nice, triangular number for us to use as a base unit deriving a sensible grid.
